Spaceflight Temporarily Changes the Position and Shape of Astronauts’ Brains, MRI Data Suggests
The biggest changes happen in brain regions involved with processing sensory information and coordinating movement, according to a new study
With humanity’s sights set on returning to the moon and eventually setting foot on Mars, understanding spaceflight’s impact on human health is crucial. So, a team of researchers has investigated some of the consequences of out-of-this-world travel on the brain and related behaviors.
Brain scan data from dozens of astronauts and participants in a spaceflight analogue suggest that while traveling beyond Earth, the brain moves higher up and farther back in the skull, and that sensory and motor regions show the biggest deformations. The findings were published on January 12 in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
“The people who went for a year showed the largest changes,” study co-author Rachael Seidler, an applied physiologist at the University of Florida, tells NBC News’ Denise Chow. “There were still some changes evident in people who went for two weeks, but duration seems to be the driving factor.”
For the study, Seidler and her colleagues examined MRI data from 26 astronauts and 24 participants of a study that mimics the effects of a long-duration spaceflight. After spending time in real or imitated space, the individuals’ brains had shifted positions and were tilted upward. Analyzing specific brain regions revealed that the biggest deformations occurred in regions important for processing sensory information and coordinating movement.
Still, there were some differences in brain changes between the astronauts and participants of the analogue study. While astronauts’ brains had moved more in the upward direction, those in the mimicked spaceflight study showed larger shifts in the backwards direction, as reported by Space.com’s Josh Dinner. What’s more, only some of the astronauts’ post-spaceflight brain changes were seen in the analogue study participants, per the outlet.
The brain probably moves around in space because the reduced gravity throws off support from the skull and soft tissues, the authors write in the paper. Microgravity can also change how fluids are distributed in the head. Seidler and her colleagues previously reported that space travel can cause the brain’s fluid-filled cavities, called ventricles, to expand, which then take around three years to recover post-flight. Most of the brain changes observed in the new study resolved themselves within about six months of returning to Earth.
Did you know? Puffy-faced astronauts
If astronauts spend a long time in microgravity, their faces may start to appear puffy, and their legs may look thinner. That’s because their bodily fluids have redistributed upward. This change can also affect astronauts’ eyes, potentially leading to vision problems.
Seidler tells NBC News that the brain changes she and her colleagues observed can cause motion sickness or disorientation in space, and balance problems when they return to their home planet. However, the team did not identify any significant symptoms, such as cognitive impairment or headaches.
The new work is among the first to show how space-induced brain shifts might affect astronauts’ ability to function on and off Earth, Mark Rosenberg, a neurologist at the Medical University of South Carolina who was not involved in the study, tells NBC News. “We knew the brain shifts upward, but does it actually have any kind of operational impact?” he says. “This study is able to make some of those associations.”
Ultimately, “the health and human performance implications of these spaceflight-associated brain displacements and deformations require further study to pave the way for safer human space exploration,” the authors write.

New Livestream Tour Takes Tourists Underneath Rome Into Never-Before-Seen ‘House of Griffins’
Beginning in March, visitors can virtually explore the 2,000-year-old subterranean dwelling, open to the public for the first time
Officials in Rome have unveiled a novel tourism experience that blends ancient architecture with modern technology: for the very first time, one of the city’s oldest and most ornate residences will be accessible to the public, albeit only via livestream video.
The brand-new tour will take visitors virtually into the House of Griffins, a subterranean dwelling on Palatine Hill (the former neighborhood of Rome’s imperial elite) that is dated between the end of the 2nd century B.C.E. and the middle of the 1st century B.C.E. A tour guide equipped with a head-mounted smartphone will walk through the space and provide live narration, while groups of up to 12 people watch from an above-ground vestibule located in the shadow of the Colosseum.
“The Colosseum Archaeological Park thus expands its cultural offerings, making accessible a previously invisible, yet well-known and documented, site,” the park’s director Simone Quilici said in a statement translated from Italian. “This extraordinary achievement is made possible by the integration of archaeology and technology, which is increasingly destined to become the standard.”The unique offering is one hopeful solution to the capital’s ongoing problem with overtourism, as officials aim to draw visitors away from only the largest and most popular attractions. With this intention in mind, the site’s restoration was one of 10 initiatives funded by the European Union’s $227 billion National Recovery and Resilience Plan.
At the same time, limiting foot traffic within the millenia-old dwelling doubles as a safety measure, both for visitors and the centuries-old artworks.
When the multi-story House of Griffins was discovered in the early 20th century by archaeologist Giacomo Boni, researchers excavated several surprisingly well-preserved chambers. An atrium and pool sit roughly at ground-level, while eight rooms, buried further underground, are accessible only by descending a “steep, perilous staircase,” writes ArtNet’s Min Chen.
The subterranean space bears colorful mosaics and tall, wall-to-wall frescoes. Two griffins, made of white stucco, are affixed to a surviving lunette. And the largest room, nestled in the home’s interior, features mirrors and marble, its ornate floors laid with green limestone and black stone depicting three-dimensional cubes.
These delicate details were maintained inadvertently. During the Roman Empire’s Augustan era, the top floors of the House of Griffins were demolished to make way for the construction of the Domus Augustana and Domus Flavia, the private and public wings of Emperor Domitian’s palace. The building’s bottom levels were subsequently filled with soil—a decision that, while meant to stabilize the ground beneath the new building, also contributed to the home’s preservation. Over time, as new temples and homes were built atop the old, the area became known as an aristocratic quarter.
“Rome is like a big lasagna,” Adriano Morabito, the co-founder of Roma Sotterranea, a company that hosts tours of Rome’s underground, tells National Geographic’s Asia London Palomba. “From the moment Rome was born until today, it has grown in an irregular manner, with layers of stratification that occurred at different times. There are many Romes, one on top of the other, and each one was influenced by the one that came before it.”
Not much is known about the Republican-era family who once lived in the House of Griffins, though the home’s proximity to high society and Pompeii-inspired art suggest its inhabitants were quite well-off.
“[The home’s] location at the highest point of the hill, its distribution over several levels that take advantage of the slopes of the Palatine Hill itself, and its preservation make it today an almost textbook reference,” Federica Rinaldi, the home’s project chief, tells Nicole Winfield of the Associated Press. “It was certainly a domus of the highest standard.”Visitor information: House of Griffins tours
- The livestreamed tours will be held every Tuesday beginning in March. They will be offered in both Italian and English.

articles.content:
Could This Portrait of an Elderly Man With a Young Woman’s Face Hidden in His Beard Be a Long-Lost Study by Peter Paul Rubens?
When a dealer saw the unsigned painting at auction, he wondered if it might be an original piece by the renowned 17th-century Flemish artist. Experts are divided on the work’s attribution
Three years ago, Belgian art dealer Klaas Muller paid less than $115,000 for an undated, unsigned painting of an elderly man. Offered online by a “lesser-known auction house in northern Europe,” the piece was billed as a study by an unknown master of the “Flemish school,” Muller tells the Guardian’s Philip Oltermann.
However, the oil-on-paper piece may be the work of Peter Paul Rubens, the renowned Flemish painter of the 17th century. When Muller first glimpsed the warm-toned painting—depicting a man gazing downward past his long, wavy beard—he recognized something in it.
“I wasn’t sure it was a Rubens. I just knew it was very Rubens-esque, so it was still a gamble,” Muller tells the Guardian. “I have a library of books about [Rubens] at home and look at them most evenings. … It’s a bit of an addiction.”
Muller also thought the man in the painting looked familiar. He guessed it was St. Peter the Apostle or the Roman god Neptune, he tells the Belgian newspaper De Standaard’s Geert Sels. Muller began combing his reference books.
Around 1612, Rubens completed a series of portraits of Jesus’ 12 apostles. Commissioned by the Spanish Duke of Lerma, the series is now owned by the Museo del Prado in Madrid. Examining the apostle portraits, Muller saw that his “auction sleeper was a dead ringer for Rubens’ St. Thomas, in which the saint glances down to read from a heavy book, presumably the Bible,” writes Artnet’s Sarah Cascone.
Encouraged, Muller continued his search. According to a social media statement from Klaas Muller Antiques, similar bearded men appear in other Rubens paintings, such as the Elevation of the Cross, The Tribute Money and The Adoration of the Magi. When the online auction came around, Muller placed the winning bid, buying the piece for a price of less than $115,000.
After the painting arrived at Muller’s home, he got even more excited. “It was very dirty, but the varnish had protected the painting very well, and I could see that it was of extremely high-quality,” he tells the Guardian. Per the statement, the piece dates to around 1609.
Muller also found that the anonymous study contains an optical illusion: a second character hidden in the man’s beard. If one turns the artwork upside down, “a second face emerges, of a young woman peeking through the flowing facial hair,” per Artnet. As Muller tells De Standaard, the painter might have reused a paper he’d already drawn on.
“This reuse of material is not incidental,” per the statement. “It testifies to Rubens’ playful intelligence and his experimental approach to composition and process.”
Last year, art historian Ben van Beneden spent months studying the piece. Van Beneden is a former director of the Rubens House, the Antwerp museum dedicated to Rubens.
“I think it’s very likely [a Rubens],” van Beneden tells the Guardian. “You have to be cautious because you are dealing with a painting that wasn’t made for the market but as a working material. But the craftsmanship is outstanding—it has a very lifelike quality.”
Quick fact: What is Peter Paul Rubens known for?
In the 17th century, the Flemish artist painted works featuring religious and mythological themes, as well as portraits and landscapes.
Still, the study hasn’t been widely confirmed as a Rubens. Nico Van Hout, the head of collections at the Royal Museum of Fine Arts Antwerp, tells Patrick Vincent of the Belgian newspaper Gazet van Antwerpen that he won’t comment on the authenticity of the painting without seeing it for himself. But he says many people come forward hoping they’ve found a masterpiece, and the chances that they’re right are usually very small.
Van Hout is a leading expert on Rubens’ study heads, the characters the artist drew in preparation for final works, per the Gazet van Antwerpen. Van Hout co-authored a book on the subject called Turning Heads.
Experts know that Rubens created a study of the head seen in St. Thomas and the other works, but it’s been lost to history. “Muller may indeed have found the prototype,” van Beneden tells the Guardian.
According to the statement, the artwork will be displayed at the BRAFA art fair in Brussels later this month, “accompanied by a note from Ben van Beneden, who has identified it as an authentic Rubens.” Until then, it will remain on the wall in Muller’s home. He hopes to loan the piece to a museum, and he tells ARTnews’ Maximilíano Durón that he’s still in the process of determining an asking price for the piece.

Archaeologists Unearth Intricately Decorated Box Carved From Deer Bone That May Have Once Held Ancient Ointments
The box was excavated from a Roman-era grave in England. It was found among a trove of artifacts spanning roughly 8,000 years of human activity
Archaeologists in England have discovered an intricately decorated box made from bone that likely dates to the late Roman period.
Researchers discovered the “beautifully carved” bone box while excavating a site called Milestone Ground in Broadway, a village in the county of Worcestershire located about 100 miles northwest of London, according to a recent announcement. Researchers with Worcestershire Archaeology, which is part of Worcestershire County Council, were digging on behalf of the local Wychavon District Council in preparation for a planned development.
They spotted the box while excavating the grave of a young woman. “We just saw this hint of a carved bone artifact below the skull, but we had no idea at that point what was actually going to come out of the ground,” says Jamie Wilkins, who led the excavation, in a video from BBC News.
Once archaeologists successfully extracted the container from the grave and took a closer look, they were stunned.
The box was recently featured on an episode of BBC Two’s “Digging for Britain” series.
“I’ve never seen anything like it before,” Wilkins says in the video. “The craftsmanship’s incredible. It’s really highly decorated as well—it looks amazing—so it was clearly a really, really special item. And for it to be deposited in the grave shows that it had some significance to that young Roman woman … but also maybe to the people around her, the wider community.”
The box is decorated with various rings and dots, and the sliding lid can be fully removed to reveal the interior space. Based on the style of the decoration, researchers initially assumed the box dated to the late Roman period. They later confirmed that hunch by radiocarbon dating the burial site.
Subsequent analyses have revealed the box was crafted from the bone of a roe deer. The researchers suspect it once contained an ointment used for pain relief, because the woman’s skeleton shows signs of lesions and joint inflammation, reports the Telegraph’s Isabella Steinmeyer.
They think the woman was between 25 and 30 when she died. She’s one of 79 bodies from the late Roman period discovered at the Milestone Ground site so far, per the Telegraph.
“Some remains are buried with the head decapitated and at the feet. Some are face down with the hands tied. Some are pushed over to the side of the grave—so there’s something in the grave with them that doesn't archaeologically survive, flowers or food, perhaps,” says Aidan Smyth, archaeology and planning adviser to the Wychavon District Council, in a video shared on the council’s YouTube page. “They’re all facing in different directions. So, there’s more questions than answers at the moment.”
More broadly, the dig has turned up evidence for roughly 8,000 years of human activity, emphasizing the village’s historic importance as a settlement along a major route across the Cotswolds. Their oldest finds date as far back as the Mesolithic period.
Quick fact: When was the Mesolithic period in Britain?
Sometimes called the Middle Stone Age, this era of history in Britain spans from roughly 9600 to 4000 B.C.E.
The researchers have discovered everything from Neolithic flint and bones to Iron Age storage pits that likely once held grains, per the council’s video. They’ve also unearthed several examples of pottery created by members of the Beaker culture, which made bell-shaped pieces during the Bronze Age.
Some of the finds were initially discovered in 2004 by children in the county’s Young Archaeologists’ Club.
“I remember walking across the field, wrapped up warm on a cold day, and finding some of this stuff,” Nathan Hazlehurst, a former club member who is now in his 30s, told BBC News’ Tom Edwards last year. “At the time, we were one of the first branches [of young archaeologists] to actually do field work like that. It’s incredible to think what's happening at the site now.”
